The same goes for physical inactivity or poor diet quality—those factors could be the real culprits, but they’re being incorrectly attributed to red meat.

In fact, when researchers do properly adjust for these confounding factors, the strength of the association between red meat and cancer often diminishes significantly. In some cases, the association disappears entirely or even reverses direction, especially when the overall quality of the diet is taken into account.

This is why it’s so important to look at the full context of the research and not take observational studies at face value—especially when they’re used to make sweeping public health recommendations. Red meat is just one piece of the dietary puzzle, and isolating its effect without considering the whole picture can lead to misleading conclusions.
